resources.string:
Congratulations on your first step toward taking control of your schedule and eliminating lateness in your professional and personal life.

This quick tour is simple to use: swipe left and right to move between pages, and swipe up and down to scroll.

Now swipe left to get started!

Turning on the NeverBeLate™ Advance Warning system is simple. On the main screen you will find a checkbox just the like the one below. Just check the box, and then rest easy knowing that NeverBeLate™ is working behind the scenes to keep you on time to all of your events.
Well, there is actually one more thing that NeverBeLate™ needs to work properly. Swipe left to learn what it is!

The simplest definition for a searchable address is one that you can search for in Google Maps. NeverBeLate™ requires each of your event locations to be a searchable address so that it can determine travel distances and times correctly. Good examples are \"221b Baker Street, London, UK\", or if you\'re in a hurry, just \"Atlanta, GA\" or even \"77059\". A good tradeoff between accuracy and speed of entry is to enter just the street address and the postal code, as shown in the example below.
If you leave the location field of an event empty, NeverBeLate™ will simply ignore it. Looks pretty easy, doesn\'t it?

\"But what if I want to use both general locations and searchable addresses in my calendar?\" Now you can! A new marked locations feature has been added to help spot the searchable addresses amongst the bad ones. Enabling marked locations is simple: look in the Settings menu to find the \"Only marked locations\" option shown below, and check the box.

Then start placing an asterisk or star (*) at the beginning of your searchable event locations, just like this: \"*Atlanta, GA\". NeverBeLate™ will then only look for the marked locations, and will ignore the rest. Next time a coworker invites you to a meeting in \"Joe\'s office\", you won\'t be warned incorrectly.

One of the most powerful features of NeverBeLate™ is the instant opportunity to check the traffic between where you are now and where you need to be. When an Advance Warning dialog pops up to warn you that it is time to leave for your next event, you will see a large green button just like the one below.

Press this button to view a colorful map showing the traffic in the area. Your current location will be marked with a blue flag, and your event location will be marked with a red flag. The traffic will be color-coded just like in Google Maps. If the traffic is red, be sure leave as soon as possible!
